The number and consistency of killings is mind-numbing and even boring after two plus hours. It's like a cartoon. Apparently there were an almost endless supply of villains to be killed. And also apparently, said villains couldn't shoot worth a hoot, hardly ever hitting or even coming close to the heroes. If the old west was really like this, no one would have survived. Everyone would have been killed. In summary, Silverado is a weak story, of nearly continuous episodes of killings and violence, too infrequently punctuated with dialog or any meaningful exposition.
It has jeff goldblum which is its only valuable asset.

Easily the best western made in the 80's after Clint Eastwood's "Pale Rider". The one place that it far outshines Pale Rider is in the large amount of humor. Pale Rider is a fantastic movie, but depressing. Silverado is a fantastic movie that leaves you smiling and wanting more. The cast is great including Kevin Kline, Scott Glenn, Danny Glover the always overrated Kevin Costner, Brian Denney full of menace, a very slick Jeff Goldblum ( until recently engaged to a girl from my town of Winnipeg, resulting in regular sightings of him here ), and even an appearance by John Cleese from across the pond. Everybody gives great performances. Even Costner is decent, probably because he only has to play a man-child. If you enjoy a good western then this is for you. The movie starts off strong and keeps up the interest right through till the end. The length of the movie is nice too, it is long enough to develop a serious story, but not of epic lengths such as the Lord of the Ring movies, which were far too long.

Review title: Great Start makes up for weak finish
Review_body: LOVED this movie until they got to Silverado, at which point it tailed off. Great mix of action and subtle humor (particularly John Cleese), but it lost its touch once they group arrived in Silverado, and Jeff Goldblum came on the scene.

Review title: A brilliant script with the perfect cast
Review_body: I finally was able to see this movie and wow was I in for a treat. I am not a mayor western fan, but I am a great admirerer of that rare thing in Hollywood movies: A Good Script. Great characters with a lot of depth and real lives walk around in Silverado and do stuff. Not because of the story, but because of who they are. Even the women are completly fleshed out and no, I am not talking about the size of their breasts. Kevin Kline is brilliant and after seeing him last week in The Wild Wild West, he completly redeemed himself, even though Silverado was made 25 years before that turkey. Even Kevin Kostner did a great job (and didn't end up on the cutting table like in the other great Kasdan movie, The Big Chill). Only the music is dated in this wonderfull adventure, were you are really scared that one of the main characters may end up dead. Because Kasdan is not playing by the rules, you get something even rarer then a great script; a western without cliches.

Review title: I didn't remember this film being so good.
Review_body: I first saw this when it first came out on Video. I thought it was OK. Recently I got the new remastered wide screen edition and it is a delight. (I knew Costner had shot two guys at once the first time but they were standing behind my speaker system that time and I couldn't see them fall.) The 'making of' segment following the feature is really interesting too. The cast is great, the action is great, the music is great. I rate this as the last great action western.
Absolutely one of the best modern westerners, with a cast of stars perfect for each role.

Review title: Band of four friends defend themselves and town against bad guys
Review_body: Roger Ebert said this movie made him think of going to Saturday matinees to see westerns and "choosing up sides" for the walk home (from the characters in the film).  It made me feel the same way.  The cast works very well together, and Kasdan keeps the tone balanced between light and serious all the way through.  The music is phenomenal, and the cinematography is fantastic.  You won't be sorry you rented it.

One comment that continues to echo through all the comments is "fun."I couldn't agree more!  I love this movie, and would recommend watching it 2 or 3 times before passing judgment.  There are too many people to figure out the first time through.Granted, not very realistic.  If you want realism, see McMurtry's "Lonesome Dove" (a 9 out of 10).I give this an 8 out of 10.  Happy Trails!

I love this movie! Sure the story is a bit trite but the characters & the actors are fantastic. Introduced me to many actors I had never seen before & am a big fan of now. Beautiful scenery. Highly recommend Silverado.

Review title: 12 or more big name actors/stars in this one
Review_body: Good clean Western escapist fun movie. Should be a classic. At least 12 big name stars, lots of character actors and fine director should have made this movie a bigger hit. It is a "10" in my book. Sit down and watch it on a rainy Saturday afternoon and you won't be disappointed.Why wasn't it a bigger hit? Maybe too many stars who had to give up screen time to each other, maybe the old fashioned Western theme and plot, maybe a studio that missed the boat on promoting it too weakly. Whatever, it is thoroughly watchable and timeless

Contempt is not an accurate word for this movie. If I could give it zero stars I would. Clap trap fantasy created for a perceived audience. Every person involved in this movie should be ashamed of themselves, but I'm sure they were too busy laughing all the way to the bank. This dreck reminds me of the "Super Hero" garbage we have to endure today.

This movie has a great cast and a pretty good plot.  It's the classic good guys versus the bad guys.  My interest was high throughout the movie. Fifteen years later, it's fun to see Kevin Kline, Kevin Costner, Danny Glover, etc.  before they became super stars.  This is good entertainment.

When it comes to classic westerns, add "Silverado" to the list.  The story is a great one, but the movie is made more powerful by the performances of it's cast.  The plot, while seemingly simple, is made more intricate as there ae really about 4 lead characters, each with his own "mission." Scott Glenn is superb as the cowboy riding to meet his brother so they can travel to California.  Kevin Kline is outstanding as Paden.  In a part that could have been overplayed, Kline is brilliant in his portrayal of a man in search of a place to put down roots.  Not outdone by either is Danny Glover, as the man seeking to reunite with his family only to find tragedy.  And Kevin Costner is hilarious as Glenn's brother, a wild fast-gun shootist.  This movie has everything you could ask for; adventure, drama, humor and terrific scenery.  I highly recomment this for fans of the western genre.

Review title: Expansive scenery, exciting action, terrific characters.
Review_body: With the breathtaking wide-open spaces of a John Ford classic Western, "Silverado" (this time from Lawrence Kasden), takes us into the high desert country of New Mexico in brilliant Technicolor.  A basic good versus evil story is brought to life with terrific characters portrayed by some of the best actors the movie industry has to offer.I recommend that you add "Silverado" to the Westerns section of your "Top Ten Desert Island" collection.  But you must see "Silverado" in the letterbox format.  The "edited to fit your TV screen" version will only leave you disappointed.

The only good part about this movie is Kevin Kline's acting. I liked Brian Dennehy's acting too. Kevin Costner played a very dumb character in this movie. The storyline does not have a solid spine to it and in the end, I just didn't feel like the time was well spent watching a movie with nothing solid about the story. This movie just didn't make it for me.
A good western.  Good to see Kevin Costner in a much different role than his recent movies.  Would have been better with Clint Eastwood in the role of Emmett.  Great soundtrack.

It's probably the best feeling Western made since the heyday of Roy Rogers. It's specially crafted to make us feel good.  There's no disturbing subtext, and it takes a very modern approach to the issue of racism.  Yes, there is racism but only the bad guys exhibit it.  And there's no injuns, because you can't have injuns in a Western nowadays without it dwelling on the redman's plight and that's just too depressing.  That's what this film gives you: the fun myth of Manifest Destiny without the sad reality of the subjugation of the native peoples.Yes, when we were kids we played cowboys and indians, but now we feel guilty about it.  Thankfully, when we were kids we also played white hat vs. black hat.  Good guys with six shooters versus bad guys with six shooters.  That's what Silverado taps into: the cool, still politically correct aspects of the Western.  Good fun without the guilt.  That's something Kasdan knows how to do.  He wrote Raiders of the Lost Ark that conjured up a similar formula for the old pulp serials.That's not to say the characters are simplistic.  They compare quite favorably to characters in such classic old Westerns as Stagecoach.  They just don't have the kind of depressing depth of character that you see in The Searchers.  There are good guys and there are bad guys and there really isn't much doubt which is which.  Still, there is really only one unsympathetic character in the whole film and that would Jeff Fahey's Tyree. You've got to have one really dirty dog in the movie, after all.  The two main bad guys are Ray Baker's underdeveloped Ethan McKendrick and the charming Cobb played by Brian Dennehy.  It's probably Dennehy's best performance.  He's Claudius in the old West, "that a man may smile and be a villain!"  Yeah, those are the best villains, not the dreary scowling ones.There are four protagonists but the star is Kevin Kline as Paden.  He's actually got a complex back story.  He used to be a criminal and ran with Cobb!  The film's approach to good vs. bad is not deterministic.  Kline's performance is cool and collected, but the character really comes to life in the scenes with Linda Hunt's Stella.  They have a real chemistry, they are kindred spirits.  Danny Glover and Scott Glenn are solid, but it is Kevin Costner who really steals the show.  This is the movie that set him on the path to stardom and he's never really given a more charismatic performance as the slightly crazy man-child samurai six shooter master Jake.Fine supporting performances are turned in by John Cleese as a sheriff with the intelligence to know when he's run across the heroes of a Western, Joe Seneca as Danny Glover's father, Lynn Whitfield as Glover's sister, the scrumptious Amanda Wyss as phoebe the barmaid, Jeff Goldblum as the gambler Slick whose alliances are always up in the air, and a curiously uncredited Brion James as the curmudgeonly coot who leads a wagon train.The plot revolves around the old conflict between farmers and ranchers.  If you think about it now I'm sure you could successfully guess all the plot points ahead of time, but when you're watching it the movie's energy takes over and you just enjoy the roller coaster ride of fun and excitement!Good, clean fun about a time we know was neither, but in the movies it can be.

Silverado is a wonderful western, and at the top of my list for such movies. It's a kick from the quirky beginning to the satisfying wrap-up.  A first-rate cast put down solid performances -- I absolutely loved the rich variety of characters. This is a 10 in my book!  Why there wasn't a sequel to this, I'll never know.

Review title: I Love a Good Western, but THIS ONE?!
Review_body: I don't know, maybe I'm just getting curmudgeonly in my old age. I love a good western flick as much as the next man, but when Silverado aired this morning, it just went "clunk".Perhaps what got under my skin is that it's just dripping with modern political correctness, a glaring anachronism for the time period portrayed. When John Cleese's character says "I don't much care for that word" in response to someone uttering the "N" word in a bar, I just lost it. (My late great aunt used the "N" word in polite dialog well into the 1970s, to her it was just a descriptive word with no baggage attached. I can't imagine that folks had similar heightened racial sensitivities in the late 1800s!) Of course, all of the real evil villains in Silverado are white males. All the heroes and heroines are persons of color, female, physically handicapped, or if they're cursed with being Anglo and male, they have some endearing internal conflict or past victimhood to excuse their gender and paleness. Yawn. It's really getting trite.How I yearn for the cowboys heroes of the old genre, simple unconflicted stories where good triumphed over evil, the bad guy had a black hat for easy identification, and the hero got the girl in the end and rode happily off into the sunset. John Wayne and John Ford, you are missed terribly these days.

Now, I've never liked Westerns very much, let's get that straight.  But "Silverado" is just plain more entertaining than most films of the genre it attempted to revive.  The cast is like a dream, with Kline, Hunt, and Costner turning in some really smashing performances.  It takes you along a basic formula Western plot -- evil fat guys doing unjust things while the protagonists decide they're not going to take it anymore -- but is set apart by humor and great characters.  Not to mention that fabulous cast !Movie rating:  10Kevin Bacon Usefulness:  9

Review title: One of the best westerns to come down the pike.
Review_body: This comment has a spoiler, but, as the film is 15 years old, I don't think that's really a concern. I first saw this on opening day and I still enjoy watching it on DVD, just last night, in fact. It certainly ranks in the top five of all time. The best scene in the film is during the shoot out at the ranch. Jake (Kevin Costner) has been declared dead from falling off a horse. When he swung down from the rafters to help Paden (Kevin Kline) in the barn scene shoot out,the audience broke out into cheers an applause. I've never seen another western that brought out such a reaction from the audience before or since. My only disappointment is that there was no sequel. At the end of the movie, when Jake calls out, "We'll be back!" as they ride off, I thought a sequel would soon follow. But, I suppose that Costner's rate probably went too high.

It would be very difficult to find another movie of this caliber with so many super-stars appearing in their early careers.  It's a slam-bang, action-packed, wryly humorous homage to the early "B" westerns.

and it's wonderful! It has good guys, bad guys, horses, a horse thief, a hat thief, a wagon train, outlaws, a saloon, a gambler, a crooked sheriff, an evil ranch owner, a "kid"napping, a fire, a stampede, a rescue, and a happy ending. It has a great cast, and everything you could want in a western. Have fun!
This film has to be one of the best westerns I have ever seen! The acting and plot are superb. And so is the theme tune - very catchy!

Silverado is fun, exciting, has funny and memorable dialogue, a simple but interesting plot that sticks to the basics, and great music to boot! Made in the mid 80's, it's also full of stars in their younger days: Kevin Klein, Scott Glenn, Kevin Costner, Danny Glover, Linda Hunt, Brian Dennehy, and even John Cleese. It also represents the first and last decent performance by Costner. Even if your not into westerns you should give Silverado a try, you won't be sorry! Where's the dog?

This film is great fun with a great cast. Kevin Kline and Linda Hunt's scenes together are the best bit of acting in the movie. As a western it manages to pay homage to nearly all Western tropes but not too seriously - gunfights, saloon fights, stampedes, posse chases, wagon drives, corrupt law enforcement and even the strong pioneer woman who really helped settle the Old West.But....the one thing I really couldn't stand was the constant reference to the character of Augie as 'the little boy.' He's not a little anything. He must be 16 years old trying to pass as 11. It just doesn't work. And because it doesn't work, there's no real heart tugging at his predictable kidnapping.But that is my only objection.

Review title: A great movie with lots of plots and stars, some, before they were famous!
Review_body: I fell in love with Kevin Costner and his character watching this movie!!! I had never seen him before but his character in Silverado is well portrayed as a carefree fun loving young adult. All his mannerisms were very endearing and unique. Scott Glenn is superb as a decent law abiding cowboy just trying to do what's right and Danny Glover's character is wholesome, earthy and strong. Brian Dennehy is great as the older villain you love to hate and Jeff Fahey is super as the younger villain who is equally as evil but a very cute bad boy. Then you have Kevin Kline who does a wonderful job playing the intelligent yet not wanting to be too serious type citizen but who always does what's right, not what's easy. John Cleese and Jeff Goldblum are terrific as well as very colorful western men. The amazing Linda Hunt is even in it as a strong woman standing her ground as is Rosanna Arquette's character. I couldn't believe it when I first saw it because of all the big names and how great all the plots were and how they were all inner twined so beautifully. I couldn't wait to find out how it all came together in the end and when it did I was not disappointed. I bought the movie as soon as I could and I still love watching it. I consider it a classic as a newer Hollywood western. I thought it was very realistic yet entertaining and exciting because of all the big names. The ones who become famous later did a fantastic job because I was immediately curious as to who they were and wondered why they weren't famous already. The action is great, the violence is effective without being too harsh, the sweet and tender moments are just right, the morals represented are wonderful even for today's lessons and I wish everyone could see it and enjoy it. It reminds me of "It's a Mad Mad Mad World" because of all that is going on and of all the stars who keep popping up while you are intensely watching it. A very great and well made movie!

Review title: One of the best western's ever made!
Review_body: This film is one of the best western's ever made.  It covers all aspects of the genre and adds a terrific story, with a little romance, drama, comedy and lots of action!  The musical score is superb and is such an enhancement to the film that it causes the viewer to become totally absorbed in the story line.  I highly recommend this film for first time western viewers!

Review title: The Greatest Western of all time
Review_body: Silverado is a staple in my collection. The plot the actors and the action all come together in a smooth flowing saga of the old west.This picture has all of the elements of a top notch movie, action, drama, comedy, and wit.So for a wonderful evening in front of the old boob tube, break out the micro wave popcorn sit the kiddies down and get ready to be entertained
What were the actor's thinking? It's not El Dorado for sure.

I just watched the later part of this movie and was startled at the mediocrity, given all the big names. Most of the stars seemed miscast, no one seemed to draw acting talent out of the stars. Must have been done at studio behest only. Phoned in, if you know what I mean, but an expensive phone call. Somehow Costner didn't even look appealing, Klein looked out of time, Dennehy looked like a canned sheriff, Goldblum also seemed like he was dressed up for the wrong century. Wonder why they bothered unless someone up high had a thing about doing a Western movie like the other studios were doing. Oh well, everyone went on to better work. Compare to Costner in Open Range and you will see a man working off a passion.

I thought this was one of the greatest cowboy movies made in modern times. It completely revived the cowboy genre of the "old" days - when the bad guys were bad and the good guys were good. That the good guys were slightly bad and could be redeemed. I'm tired of movies that the lines of who is good and who is bad is extremely blurred. I realize this is a black and white attitude; but in today's society, we need to return to that value. I grew up on John Wayne and Gary Cooper and Clint Eastwood movies. They were Westerns you wanted to watch - the good guys fighting for the little people and overcoming the odds (which was really impossible, we knew, but we wanted it to be that way). It harks back to the view that movies should entertain - and Silverado entertains from start to finish. I loved Kevin Kline; and Scott Glenn as the monosyllabic cowboy was fantastic. From the opening scene, reminiscent of all the good ole cowboy flicks, to the closing--maybe we'll make a sequel (extremely too bad that they didn't)--ending, you enjoy and are entertained.

Review title: An Homage that works on it's own
Review_body: Many other people here have commented on how formulaic this movie is. Sure it is- it's Kasdan's tribute to the Westerns he loves. One doesn't write a tribute to the Beatles without some kind of imitation. Take it for what it is, on that level.But it's also a great movie on it's own. The acting is terrific, the plot is pretty much what the plot of a Western is supposed to be, and we all agree on the scenery and music.I have trouble with some of the other (negative) reviews. Several state that the characters are too black and white. I didn't see it. Look at the 4 main characters. Emmet is just out of prison, for murder. Justified? Sure, but still "murder". Paden is a reformed crook, seemingly trying to go straight. Mal is a "black sheep" whose family thinks he abandoned them. And Jake-well he's immature, and thinks with his guns. (All three of them.) How are they too good and pure? The movie is about writing wrongs, and redeeming oneself, so there have to be some skeletons buried.The actors portraying the main 4 do a great job. Scott Glenn makes Emmet a man of iron will. Kevin Kline's Paden is a fatalist, just trying to keep alive. Danny Glover plays Mal as a man that wants to be treated as a man, with dignity and the desire for what's right. And Kevin Costner is just having a rollicking good time.The bad guys are somewhat formulaic I agree, though I think Brian Dennehy as Cobb comes across as a crook who is trying to (sorta) go straight. Sure he'll do what he has to, but he's found a place where he thinks he can fit in, and he'll do what has to be done to keep it. Jeff Fahey as Tyree is terrific- there's not enough of him. He's a complete psychopath, but Fahey does a great job- he's got the whole "Helter Skelter" eyes thing going on.Other roles are less interesting. I agree that Jeff Goldblum's "Slick" is not much, nor well-played. I think the idea of the crooked gambler was good, but the part didn't work out well. Too bad. John Cleese worked as a sheriff. Sure, he added a light touch, and I think the role was written specifically for him (just a hunch), but he's also a realist. He wants to keep the peace in his town, and that's it. If the Bad Guys get away, well good riddance. Just don't come back.I did like Rosanna Arquette. She played a hard-working woman with some "funny" ideas. Understated, and true. It's impossible to make her look anything less than breath-taking, but they dressed her in a matronly fashion, and avoided the temptation to have her bathe in a convenient body of water, which broke my heart then and now.As for the story, well so what if the climax was predictable. This is a movie- it's not a documentary. The good guys win, and the bad guys die for their sins. Duh. Was it surprising that Cobb and Paden faced off in the street? No, but that's what one expects in a Western. And it was done well. Both men knew it was coming, and both faced Fate, knowing that their friendship (if that's the right word) means nothing. Lots of bad guys got killed, but that's what happens when you back the wrong horse. They made their choices, and it ended badly.I think that the biggest problem here is the lack of background. As mentioned above, the characters have histories that bring them all together here, but we don't know any more. Why did Mal leave his family? What is the background of Paden, and so on. Given the length of the movie, none of this could be covered, which is why a prequel would be a great idea. Perhaps LK could do one now, with different actors portraying the younger men and women....? So overall, it's a great movie, and a great western. It pays tribute to the great ones that went before, even requiring the same suspension of disbelief as some of them. But it's a good vs. evil story, and succeeds well. Was it as "real" as Eastwood's "Unforgiven" (which I found boring)? Probably not, but Clint was going for the Anti-western. Kasdan went for the real thing. What he achieved is a classic movie of it's genre. Watch it, know it, love it.

Review title: Classic Proof? Can be watched 100's of times!
Review_body: The is the true test of a classic, how many time you can stare at it ... not to mention that even if you're on your 20th time it's difficult to leave the room because that "line" or "that scene" are just about to come up. One of the delights of this movie are the character that pop up in each new town the venture through ... the scene with Paden and his horse, the next town and the characters with his hat ... Oh, my goodness John Cleese's Langston his part is so short yet so sweetly perfect. Then to imagine it's not until they finally arrive in Silverado that we meet the unbeatable embodiment of grace and confidence Miss Stella played by Linda Hunt and if that is enough special surprises along the way you still get to meet "Slick" (Jeff Goldblum) when he comes to town. When I read through the quotes for this movie I realized the best way to support my nine is to say the entire script should be there. My family and many others I met are obsessed with the script ... many of the lines are household phrases we use over and over again ... I think they missed ... "Yer empty Mr.". Watch for the facial expressions between Paden and Stella when they're attempting to "stay of of the middle" of the town trouble. Linda Hunt's one look, when she figures out what "Cobb has on him this time" should win her an academy award. We have a whole room at our cabin devoted to Silverado. I guess someone could watch it and say, yeah, this is kinda dull ... I guess. It's NOT ... it's all about the one liners and amazing acting ... Lawrence's other movies are great but when you see the humor than Mark Kasdan adds to things you'll be pleasantly surprised. Buy it, own it, watch it over and over and over again and we'll play "what line follows" when our paths cross.

Review title: simply the finest western ever made
Review_body: What a fun movie!  L.K. did a great job with writing and directing this movie.  He made it the way he wanted and did things to ensure that his audience was never bored.  Right from the opening scene we are drawn into this movie.  Can you believe this cast! They clicked together each making their character memorable.  He used a beautiful location also.  I Recommend this movie to anyone who likes  westerns, good acting and great quotes. Do you remember some of those lines! "Can't you see this horse loves me- I had women do that to me once,that didn't make her my wife",  "I don't want kill you and you don't wanna be dead", "I love the smell of a good saloon","That ain't right,I've had a belly full of what ain't right" Oh well I like it anyway!Johnny on the movie spot

Review title: Waste of time for serious movie buffs
Review_body: So many high class actors selling out. The best scenes for me was Costner's riding and gun handling skills. After that, total disappointment. Predictable situations. Over drawn shoot-outs along with the stunts. Most of the lines are clichés. "That's the good stuff" - referring to a bottle of whiskey - give me a break. And the music? C'mon - every chance you get we have a symphony. The actors who appeared in this should feel ashamed that so many people still buy it. The story drags on and on and on. Couldn't wait for the credits and now I am thinking I shouldn't have. So sad the end product unintentionally became a pathetic self-parody. A real time waster.

Review title: I always love watching this movie.............
Review_body: SILVERADO was released in 1985 and brought westerns back to America and the world. SILVERADO was a sleeper that did excellent here in the states and Europe. It has continued to be a popular rental and has actually become a cult classic. Its popularity has continued to appeal to new audiences that were not even born when it was released. Hat's off to Lawrence Kasdan for hiring the best gun coach in the business, Arvo Ojala (1920-2005). Arvo was the father of fast draw, a sport born from the television westerns of the 1950's. Arvo was the fast draw expert who taught all the big name stars their gun handling skills. His job on SILVERADO was to make Kevin Costner proficient with a pair of Colt Single Action Army revolvers and by the way Kevin handled them in the movie, it seems that Arvo taught him well. If you have never seen this movie, go rent it. You will end up buying your own copy!

Review title: When the music started, I was 10 again.
Review_body: A GREAT western! Fantastic actors and villains die by the dozen. What more can you ask for? Costner was incredible as an ADHD teenager (almost). Will enjoy it again soon.

Review title: SIlverado The Birth of a Western Hero
Review_body: Silverado 1985 spoilersAs far as westerns go there're two big names Clint Eastwood and John Wayne. I would like to submit another name for the famous western actors Kevin Costner. Kevin Costner has been in Wyatt Earp, dances with wolves, open range, etc. My favorite Western to feature Kevin Costner is Silverado. As a whole I feel Silverado is under appreciate. The story is unique featuring a group of heroes who are less then honorable. We first me Emmitt (Scott Glenn) in a lonely dusty cabin in the middle of nowhere. The silence is broken by the sounds of gunfire and a battle rages. Next we meet Paden (Kevin Kline) a man left stranded in the desert by his friends. Paden and Emmitt head out to find Emmitt's younger brother Jake (Kevin Costner). Jakes being held in prison for murder. The trio ends up staging a jailbreak and head off toward Silverado. Along the journey, they Mal( Danny Glover) a man headed home to help his Paw. The group of four men end up taking up a common cause and ending the reign of tyranny in Silverado. As far as westerns go Silverado has a lot of heart and Kevin Costner's character Jake made a large impact on me growing u. Jakes the ultimate wild card and the reason I give Silverado an 8/10

Review title: If you didn't watch close, you haven't seen the best western ever
Review_body: I saw this movie in it's original release and thought "good flick, but hard to follow". Now I've seen what apparently is the new and improved cut and it contains many more scenes and fleshes the story out into a real western. The story line is actually coherent, the bad guys aren't cartoonish, the good guys aren't lippy, the humor is understated, subtle and hilarious, and the running dog joke goes right up to the end. With apologies to Gary Cooper etc., Scott Glenn as Emit is the Ur cowboy of all times, while Costner, Glover, and the hated Kevin Kline all turn in what may be the performances of their lives. The rest of the cast, especially Brian Denehey, turn in fine roles. Plenty of great lines, the cinematography is breathtaking, along with the stark backdrop of the southwest U.S. in winter. Which is not to say it gets a whole lot less stark in summer. bottom line. Top Western, Top Twenty all time. I'm out.howard

As a parody this movie has it all. Taciturn cowboy. (Danny Glover, "That ain't right.") Corrupt Sheriff. (Dennehy) Crooked gambler. (Goldblum) Fallen woman with a heart of gold. (Hunt). Saving the ranch. Range bullies. Dishonest wagon master. Super gunfighter. (Costner shooting two guns in two directions at once). Jail break. A Posse. (Led by Cleese) Duel in the street at the end. Hostages. Unbelievable rifle shots by Glover. The only thing missing is the fancy Double Buscadero rig and the Roy Rogers Costume. (Oh yeah. Jake does that on a Pinto horse while doing gymnastics backwards. Never mind.) This movie isn't a Western, it's THE western. There isn't a major cliché left out of it and every cliché in it is well done. To me it appears to be loosely based on John Wayne's 'Tall in the Saddle': (TITS) as we GRITS collectors call it (GRITS being Ghost Riders in the Sky). The title 'Siverado' is a play on the Edgar Allen Poe Poem entitled 'El Dorado' and is as good a tongue in cheek parody of Hollywood film making as we are likely to see any time soon.
At the end they said they would be back. When are they all going to get together and make a sequel???

If there's a trinity of great western films in the modern era, they are: Unforgiven, Tombstone, and Silverado. Three very different films, but each fantastic in their own way. Unforgiven is the artist's western...mature, superbly crafted, dark and reflective. Tombstone is the embellished historical action/drama, based on true events. And Silverado is a wildly fun fictional homage to the great westerns of old.The acting in Silverado sets it apart from other attempts at remaking the old western. Kline, Glenn, Glover and Costner play 4 very different men, and the commitment to character makes them each believable, despite their near- superhuman abilities with a gun. The score is resounding and Oscar-nominated. The cinematography is breathtaking. The production design is fantastic and the costuming, etc., has withstood the test of time and aged wonderfully. Still feels authentic 35 years later. The action is relentless and deftly handled.The plot is a little more complex than is perhaps necessary...but it IS a Kasdan movie after all. This movie is still fun all these years later. It holds up. It's really a shame they never made a sequel...very shortsighted by the studios.
Star power, great story, and Linda Hunt just shines above it all. I'm not even a fan of Westerns in general, but I'll watch this as often as I can in the time I have left.
This is undoubtedly my all-time favorite western, with Open Range a close second...
The actors are still alive and Netflix has done a ton for movies lately... It's time for the final ending for Silverado...
